newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Hub natgas ends mixed, Aug. gains on heat.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Hub natgas ends mixed, Aug. gains on heat.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures ended mixed Tuesday in a moderate session, with near record power demand in the East lifting front months, while some deferreds finished slightly lower, sources said.
August climbed 1.1 cents to close at $2.162 per million British thermal units. September settled one cent higher at $2.156. Other deferreds ended narrowly mixed.

"We struggled to move higher on the heat, but the weather is supposed to moderate soon and the market looks like it's running out of steam," said one Midwest trader, adding much of the buying seemed to be short covering, not new length.
Many remained wary of the latest move up, with new supply coming on stream and another sizeable stock build expected in this week's AGA inventory report.
Early injection estimates for Wednesday's report range from 78 bcf to 101 bcf. For the same week last year, stocks gained 94 bcf.

Chart traders agreed the sharp decline Monday in August open interest indicated yesterday's rally was mostly short covering, likely triggered by the spot contract's move above resistance in the $2.15 area. They pegged August resistance along the down trendline in the $2.23 area. Support was seen at last week's $2.051 low, with psychological buying at $2.

In the cash Tuesday, Gulf Coast gas firmed three cents to the high-teens. Midcon pipes were four cents higher at about $2.10. New York city gate gas jumped more than a nickel to the low-to-mid $2.50s on near-record power demand in the area.
Temperatures over much of the nation are expected to remain above-normal for most of the week, but more seasonal weather is expected for the eastern half of the nation later this week and next.
The NYMEX Henry Hub 12-month strip rose one-half cent to $2.223. NYMEX said 34,699 contracts traded, up from Monday's revised tally of 26,967.

On the KCBT, August finished one cent higher at $2.06, while deferreds ended up by 0.9 to 1.9 cents. The East/West spread widened by 0.1 cent to 10.2 cents (NYMEX premium). KCBT said 315 lots traded, up from Monday's total of 177.
